body:
is the old undo behavior in the browser still in place?
maybe this pr is a good opportunity to fix #119

will test the app tonight - thx
@schiesbn looks like rebase is required

@deepdiver1975 the old behaviour is still in place. until now i saw it as an additional feature. the easy undo directly after an operation is nice in cases where i choosed the wrong file by accident and want to revert it immediately without switching to a different view while the trash bin is more useful for cases where i want to get a file back deleted a few hours or days ago.

but if we agree that the direct undo option should be removed completely than i'm also fine with it.

according to #119 we have issues with the current implementation of the undo feature.

what about reusing the undo notification (from a ux point of view) but change the implementation and trigger the undo on th last deletion within the trash bin.

summoning the rest ....
@karlitschek @jancborchardt @mtrichards @dragotin @danimo
hmm. we are running out of time here. i think it is o.k. to have this as an relatively independent feature and keep the old notification for now. #119 has to be fixed of course.

@deepdiver1975 reusing the undo notification is not that easy because the file name of the file in the trash bin is a combination of the name and the timestamp at the time of deletions. this allows to have more than one file with the same name in the trash bin. the timestamp is created when the file is copied to the trash bin, so it is not possible for the files app to know this timestamp.

on the other hand removing the undo notification should be quite easy if we agree that we no longer need it with the trash bin app.
the plan was to not have an independent trash app, but include it in a status page. i want to hold off on this until the rest is done...

@schiesbn would be the easiest solution for now to just remove the old system. i hope @jancborchardt is not killing us if we do this. ;-)
remember that we are not aiming for the ultimate solution here but an improvement for owncloud 5 which won't be the last owncloud release ;-)
@mtgap we can do the status page for owncloud 6. but for now this is a nice and very useful feature that many users want.
the trash bin app would disappear between owncloud 5 and 6. changing around the ux like that isn't ideal.
@mtgap true.  we should still go with the simple solution that works now instead of the complex solution that we might have later, perhaps.:-)

@mtgap additionally a lot (if not all) of the trash bin app can be reused with the status page planed for oc6. what might change that the status page will introduce another view on the trash bin. additionally to the current one or as an replacement. time will tell. but no reason to have no trash bin in oc5 at all.
@lukasreschke thanks for pointing this out! unfortunately i missed the thread on the mailing list. i removed the inline js and fixed the comment.
@schiesbn how does the trash bin behave with external fs?

it doesn't distinguish between different storages. if a file gets deleted it is moved to the trash bin. if the user restores the file it gets moved to the previous folder which in case of an external storage is the external storage again. if the previous folder no longer exists the file/folder gets restored in the users root folder.

ok - let's think of following scenario:
there is a file with a few hundreds  mb on dropbox. 
the deletion will download the whole file to the local fs into the trash bin.

is there enough space on the local fs? (movie)
deletion will be a long running operation - how will the ux be in this case?

from my point of view we cannot treat remote fs the same as local fs.

btw: same scenario is interesting for versioning.

@deepdiver1975 i see your point. what would be your suggestion? use the trash bin only for local files? or only for files up to a specific size? add a size limit only for remote storages? the drawback here, all of this options will result in a unpredictable behaviour for the user.

maybe a trash bin on each fs ?
would be ideal but takes time to implement.â 

for the first version maybe only on local fs. on remote fs it's a real delete maybe with confirmation dialog to the user.

i also thought about this option. but this also has some drawbacks:

- this will not solve the disk space issue you described but just move it to another storage.

- we would spam the remote storage with ugly owncloud specific folders/files which would be shown to the user if he access the storage directly.

- if the remote storage gets removed (from the user or the admin) the user will lose access to his trash bin.
 
for comparison i also looked at some trash bin implementations on the gnu/linux desktop. they always copy the file to ~/.local/share/trash. so they have exactly the same problem if the user mount external storages or access them with his favourite file manager. that's not a reason not to try to come up with a better solutions but maybe an indicator that there is no perfect solution.

> this will not solve the disk space issue you described but just move it to another storage.

naturally speaking the crap stay where is belongs! ;-)

> we would spam the remote storage with ugly owncloud specific folders/files which would be shown to the user if he access the storage directly.

well - this depends if we can re-use existing trash bin features of the remote fs.
even if not we can hide it in the web view.

> if the remote storage gets removed (from the user or the admin) the user will lose access to his trash bin.

which is okay i'd say. if i have no longer access to data on a remote fs - this has a reason and i should not be capable to restore the data from the trash bin.
(scenario might we that a user belongs to a different business unit and due to that other access permissions apply.)

one other thing, which comes to my mind:
will the trash bin work on files, which have been shared with me?
no - i guess - because delete is treated as unshare - right?
how will the undo work in this case? :imp:

> well - this depends if we can re-use existing trash bin features of the remote fs. even if not we can hide it in the web view.

we can hide it in our web interface but not in the web interface of dropbox, google or if i access my samba, ftp, webdav resource with other clients beside owncloud. this is really ugly. at least i would hate it if a app would spam my folder this way.

> which is okay i'd say. if i have no longer access to data on a remote fs - this has a reason and i should not be capable to restore the data from the trash bin.

you could argue this way. on the other hand you could say that the remote storage should be completely transparent to the user. he doesn't care where the files are stored. if the remote storage was configured by the admin he even doesn't know that he is using a remote storage. what most users probably care about is that they can rely on a consistent behaviour like "i deleted yesterday something -> i will find it in the trash bin".

>will the trash bin work on files, which have been shared with me?
> no - i guess - because delete is treated as unshare - right?

it depends. if i have write permissions on the shared folder than a "delete" is a real "delete". in this case the file will of course go to the trash bin like every other deleted file. but you are right about the "unshare"-delete-operation. i have to check if this also triggers a delete hook.

> it depends. if i have write permissions on the shared folder than a "delete" is a real "delete". in this case the file will of course go to the trash bin like every other deleted file.

in which trash bin will it go? the original user? the share-partner? both? how will the restore work? 
sorry to ask all these questions, but some one has to ask them? ;-)

> in which trash bin will it go? the original user? the share-partner? both? how will the restore work?
> sorry to ask all these questions, but some one has to ask them? ;-)

no problem, that's what the review process is for, right?

it goes to the trash bin of the user who deleted the file. i thought that this is the natural behaviour. the user who shared the file allowed the recipient to delete the file so he has to expect that the file gets deleted. the user who deletes the file expect that he can undo it with the trash bin that's why the file is in his trash bin.

i checked the "unshare"-delete-operation. at the moment this files also goes to the trash bin, which of course is wrong. but this is a bug of the files-app and the sharing-app, unshare should be handled different than the delete operation and not trigger any delete hooks.

i put this on my todo-list for the bug-hunting phase. i think it is better to sort this out once the new sharing and all the other pieces are in place. at the moment it is not really possible to test and fix this parts in master.

> no problem, that's what the review process is for, right?

hehe - well - this is more concept work what we are doing right now - should have been done before coding! *hiding* :smile: 

> it goes to the trash bin of the user who deleted the file. ....

reasonable - we need to document this very well.
i already see the issues popping up:  my shared file has been deleted, but it's not in the trash bin ..... bla bla
;-)

> hehe - well - this is more concept work what we are doing right now - should have been done before coding!

it was done before coding. i just explaining the concept to you now because you ask for it ;-)

> i already see the issues popping up: my shared file has been deleted, but it's not in the trash bin ..... bla bla

yes, but can be explained quite easy: the trash bin is the place where you can restore the files you deleted. have you deleted the file? no? than you know why it is not in your trash bin ;-)

> it was done before coding. i just explaining the concept to you now because you ask for it ;-)

we could have saved a lot of ping-pong here if the result of the concept phase would have been written down and communicated where to find it.

> yes, but can be explained quite easy ...

sure - i'd love to close such bugs by simple copy'n'paste a link to the docs.
unsharing a file from your self and the filesystem emitting the delete hook is not a bug... it calls the shared storage's unlink function like it should.

@mtgap the problem is, that it triggers the delete hooks and for other apps there is no way to detect if the files was really deleted or just unshared. i think it would be better to call a "unshare" action if this is the action we want to perform. this would also allow to trigger corresponding hooks and react on it if needed. maybe there are other options to solve the problem, i didn't thought this through yet. but we need a way know if a files was "deleted" or just "unshared". intuitive it doesn't make sense to call delete hooks if nothing was deleted.

but this is nothing which can be solved in the trash bin app. so this pull request can be reviewed independently from this issue.

it shouldn't be separated from the unlink action. after receiving the delete hook you should call isdeletable and then getowner to figure out if the file will be deleted and where to move it to. this needs to be done not only in the case of shared files, but for other files without delete permission as well.
